Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Alteration of mantle peridotite: Geochemical fluxes and dynamics of far from equilibrium transport
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project involves an interdisciplinary study of hydration, carbonation and oxidation of mantle peridotite interacting with aqueous fluids at temperatures below ~ 300C. The PIs will combine observations of outcrops and boreholes, geochemical analyses, structural measurements, geomechanical experiments and numerical modeling to investigate feedback between alteration and fluid transport, and to quantify the resulting geochemical fluxes. Field observations and sampling will take place mainly in the Samail ophiolite of Oman, where peridotite has undergone spreading-ridge-related hydrothermal alteration, hydration and carbonation in the hanging-wall of the subduction zone that emplaced the ophiolite over metasediments, and subaerial weathering. The PIs project will provide matching funds and results that dovetail with the 2015-2018 International Continental Scientific Drilling Program (ICDP) Oman Drilling Project, and the many other related efforts just getting underway. The PIs will continue their independently supported research on subduction zone alteration of mantle wedge peridotites at a range of pressures and temperatures, and work closely with other groups investigating seafloor and subduction-related peridotite alteration, in order to quantify the similarities and differences in alteration processes in these different tectonic environments. They will generalize their results to global alteration processes and geochemical cycles.

Alteration of peridotite is an essential process in Earth dynamics. Hydration of oceanic crust and mantle, followed by subduction, supplies water to drive arc volcanism, and modulates the hydrogen content of the mantle over time. Carbonate formation during alteration of peridotite, near the surface and in the hanging wall in subduction zones, is an important but poorly characterized link in the carbon cycle. Oxidation of minerals and concomitant reduction of fluids produces H2 and hydrocarbons, and a niche for chemosynthetic microbes. Chemical weathering is as important as magmatism and plate tectonics in shaping the Earths surface. The interplay of chemical and physical mechanisms of peridotite alteration is not well understood, but will be transformed as a result of emerging understanding of equilibria and kinetics in peridotite alteration, and reaction-driven cracking that has left us poised on the brink of a breakthrough at this little-studied frontier. The PIs will take advantage of low temperature, near surface, active peridotite alteration in Oman to study inputs, outputs, and the reaction zone in situ. Such a study is more difficult in smaller peridotite exposures with limited outcrop and more rainfall, nearly impossible in submarine hydrothermal systems, and completely impossible in studies of ancient systems. Such a comprehensive approach via 250 to 600 meter boreholes is very rare, if not unprecedented.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award 1516300 funded specific research on far-from equilibrium hydration, carbonation and oxidation of mantle peridotite at < 300°C, and provided operational support for the Oman Drilling Project, OmanDP. NSF provided about 25% of OmanDP funding. The OmanDP Team includes more than 250 scientists from 20 countries. About 180 participated in onsite curation and handling of core in Oman, and/or core description onboard Drilling Vessel Chikyu in Japan. These scientists came together for scientific drilling of the Samail ophiolite, a block of oceanic crust and upper mantle hrust onto the margin of the Arabian subcontinent from about 96 to 70 Ma. Our goals were, and are, to study formation and hydrothermal alteration of oceanic crust at a spreading center, mass transfer from subducting sediments into the overlying mantle wedge during intra-oceanic thrusting and emplacement of the ophiolite, ongoing weathering - particularly, far-from-equilibrium weathering of tectonically exposed mantle peridotite in the subaerial environment and the subsurface, and the microbial ecosystem supported by chemical potential energy generated by redox in this weathering environment.

We obtained nearly 100% recovery of 3.2 km of core from sites in lower oceanic crust (GT! & GT2, 2 x 400 meters), across the sheeted dike- gabbrotransition (GT3, 400 meters), from altered peridotite through the basal thrust and into the metamorphic sole (BT1, 300 meters), across the crust-mantle transition zone (CM1 & CM2, 400 + 300 meters), and in actively weathering mantle peridotite in the"Multi-Borehole Observatory" (MBO: BA1, BA3 and BA4, 400 + 2 x 300 meters). Core was shipped to Japan for description onboard DV Chikyu, for four months in 2017 and 2018, following IODP core description protocols. Unique to operations onboard DV Chikyu were X-ray CT imaging of the full core, high resolution IR imaging of the cut core face, and XRF scanning of parts of the cut core face. In addition to cored holes, we drilled 6 inch rotary holes for extensive downhole logging and experiments at Sites CM1 and CM2 (400 & 300 m),BA1 (Holes BA1A, BA1C and BA1D), and BA2. Additional downhole experiments were conducted at Water Ministry monitoring wells.

Drilling operations, onsite curation, core description, and some logging data are published and in press in an online volume similar to the IODP Initial Reports: Kelemen, P.B., Matter, J.M., Teagle, D.A.H., Coggon, J.A.,and the Oman Drilling Science Team (2020) Proceedings of the Oman Drilling Project: College Station, TX (IODP).doi:10.14379/Oman.ph1-2.proc.2020, at http://publications.iodp.org/other/Oman/OmanDP.html. Additional data are archived at ICDP Potsdam, available online at https://www.icdp-online.org/projects/world/asia/oman/.  

The International Conference on Ophiolites and Oceanic Lithosphere (iCOOL, https://conferences.squ.edu.om/icool/) was held at Sultan Qaboos University in January 2020, involving ~ 120 participants. An abstract volume is available at https://www.omandrilling.ac.uk/. A Special Issue of J. Geophys. Res., “Ophiolites and Oceanic Lithosphere, with a focus on the Samail ophiolite in Oman” is in progress. Papers are reviewed as they arereceived, and publshed online when accepted. Papers for this Issue can be submitted until June 30, 2021.

Over the lifetime of the grant, the PI's, and collaborators in tOmanDP published about 50 papers on results of research supported in part by this grant in peer-reviewed journals, and made more than 200 presentations at international scientific meetings (AGU, EGU and JpGU, Goldschmidt Conference, and "iCOOL", as mentioned above.

Specific research results include (1) quantification of the rate of ongoing peridotite weathering in tectonically exposed peridotite of the Samail ophiolite in Oman (several percent serpentinization in the 1000 to 10,000 year time scale, and ongoing reactions buffer present-day fluid composition in the alkaline, peridotite hosted aquifer), (2) a reevaluation of subduction zone carbon fluxes, with the result that most of the CO2 in subducted sediment and basalts is likely to be recycled via dissolution in aqueous fluids and/or transported upward in solid, low viscosity diapirs in addition to previously modeled decarbonation reactions, (3) quantification of the CO2-content and depth of origin of subduction zone fluids that formed 100% carbonated peridotites in the mantle wedge (fluids migrated updip from ≥ 2 GPa to ≤ 1.2 GPa), (4) quantification of the pressure of crystallization for hydration of lime (CaO) to produce portlandite (Ca(OH)2) and of bassanite (CaSO4•0.5H2O) to produce gypsum (CaSO4•2H2O), (5) creation of new thermodynamic and physical models of volume change, stress and "reaction-driven cracking" during peridotite hydration and carbonation, demonstrating the origin of observed, natural alteration veins with orthogonal branches and confirming that stresses generated by volume changes during weathering and alteration are more than sufficient to exceed cohesive strength, produce fractures, facilitate frictional sliding along fractures, and drive pressure solution of weak phases, (6) initial quantitative characterization of the flux of H2 produced by ongoing redox reactions during peridotite weathering, and (7) characterization of the subsurface microbial ecosystem for which these redox reactions form the energetic base of the food chain, including abundant methanogens in characteristic, high pH, alkaline peridotite aquifers.
